title: 103_hr3666
content:
The Act may be cited as the "George C. Marshall Commemorative Coin Act of 1993" and pertains to the issuance of George C. Marshall Commemorative Coins. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 500,000 $1 coins to commemorate the end of World War II and General George C. Marshall's service during the war. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. The design will feature George C. Marshall's likeness on the obverse side, with a value designation, the year "1995", and other inscriptions. The coins minted under this Act in 1995 will have inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with specific groups and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Advisory Committee for the coins authorized by this Act. The Secretary may mint and issue coins in uncirculated and proof qualities, using only one facility of the United States Mint for each quality. Sales of the coins can begin on January 1, 1995, and minting must cease after December 31, 1995. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

The coins authorized under this Act shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, a surcharge of $7 per coin, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a reasonable discount, and prepaid orders will also receive a discount. 

SEC. 7. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. SEC. 7. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

Surcharges from coin sales will be paid to the Friends of George C. Marshall for the construction of the George C. Marshall Memorial and Visitor Center in Uniontown, Pennsylvania. The Comptroller General will audit the expenditures until all funds are received and accounted for. Financial assurances will be provided. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net costs to the Government for minting coins. Payments for coins require full payment, security, or a guarantee of payment from a depository institution. SEC. 10. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. SEC. 10. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws.
